Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Development and Application of Crumpled Graphene Oxide-Based Nanocomposites as a Platform Material for Advanced Water Treatment

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1454656
Fortner

CAREER: Development and Application of Crumpled Graphene Oxide-Based Nanocomposites as a Platform Material for Advanced Water Treatment

Water is critical to sustainability in the 21st Century. There are numerous aspects to water sustainability with one of those being development of new treatment processes which utilize new materials. This CAREER proposal directly benefits society as it will provide fundamental scientific understanding and information to help address the critical, global need for continued development of novel and advanced water treatment technologies. The PI will broadly disseminate project related scientific results through publication in peer-reviewed journals, presentation at conferences, and through the organization of symposiums at national meetings of the American Chemical Society. Additionally, this project incorporates a five year, comprehensive educational and outreach plan, which is designed to 1.) provide unique educational opportunities for an estimated 500 students in the St. Louis region, including over 450, 6-12th grade students; 2.) create specific and hands-on, project related, research opportunities for numerous undergraduate researchers (20-30 students); and 3.) directly support two Ph.D. students.

Technically, this project aims to systematically engineer, fundamentally characterize and broadly demonstrate 3D, crumpled graphene oxide platform composites for improved performance and, in some cases, enabling innovative (re)design strategies for advanced water treatment technologies. This project is highly novel and timely in that engineered, nanocomposite crumpled graphene oxide materials have, to date, not been evaluated as platform materials for advanced, aqueous based photocatalysis or as multifunctional membrane components, despite distinct material/engineering advantages, including: intrinsic porosities, highly tailorable photocatalytic and magnetic properties, tunable (carbon) surface chemistry and physical size/shape regimes, high aqueous and chemical stabilities, and scalable production routes. The fundamental nature of this work will not only directly support and inform the next generation of 3D graphene based composite structures for environmental applications but will also serve a wide range of researchers focused on engineering (curved) carbon-based nanostructures for advanced sensing, catalysts, photovoltaics, antifouling/antimicrobial surfaces, among other applied materials.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF CAREER award focused on the development and demonstration of three dimensional (3D), nanoscale, crumpled graphene oxide (CGO) composites as multifunctional, platform materials for advanced water treatment. The project was designed with four interrelated foci that included novel material design and synthesis, material characterization, advanced applications in water treatment, and STEM education. 

The intellectual merit of this project was significant resulting in multiple, high-impact peer reviewed journal articles, a patent, and a number of presentations. Findings from the project were novel in that engineered, nanocomposite CGO materials had not been previously evaluated as platform materials for advanced, aqueous based photocatalysis or as multifunctional membrane components.  Through this CAREER award, we demonstrate significant (nano)material/engineering advantages, including: intrinsic material porosities, highly tailorable photocatalytic and magnetic properties, tunable (carbon) surface chemistry and physical size/shape regimes, high aqueous and chemical stabilities, and scalable production routes. Taken together, data from the project underpin new and exciting directions for graphene based membranes (or even surfaces) with outstanding application potential.  The fundamental nature of this work will also serve a wide range of researchers focused on engineering (curved) carbon-based nanostructures for advanced sensing, catalysts, photovoltaics, antifouling/antimicrobial surfaces, among other applied materials.  With regard to broader impacts, this CAREER award directly benefits society as it provides fundamental scientific understanding and information to address the critical, global need for next-generation water treatment technologies.  The award supported hands-on, project related, research opportunities for numerous undergraduate researchers and directly support four Ph.D. students, one winning a highly prestigious thesis award.  Students gained highly interdisciplinary and collaborative experience(s) at the interface of material science, analytical chemistry, chemical engineering, and environmental engineering and science,  allowing them to consider a diverse range of future STEM career paths.  

Selected outcomes from this CAREER award:

  • US Patent, "Composite Nanostructures Having a Crumpled Graphene Oxide Shell,” US20190060840A1
  • Yi Jiang, Wei-Ning Wang, Di Liu, Yao Nie, Wenlu Li, Jiewei Wu, Fuzhong Zhang, Pratim Biswas, John D. Fortner, “Engineered Crumpled Graphene Oxide Nanocomposite Membrane Assemblies for Advanced Water Treatment Processes,” Environmental Science and Technology, 49 (11), p.6846–6854, 2015. 
  • Yi Jiang, Di Liu, Minjung Cho, Seung Soo Lee, Fuzhong Zhang, Pratim Biswas, John D. Fortner, “In Situ Photocatalytic Synthesis of Ag Nanoparticles on Crumpled Graphene Oxide Composite Membranes for Filtration and Disinfection Applications,” Environmental Science and Technology, 50 (5), p.2514–2521, 2016.
  • Yi Jiang, Ramesh Raliya, Pratim Biswas, John D. Fortner, “Graphene Oxide Aggregation in Water: Evaluating the Interplay Between Material and Natural Organic Matter Properties,” Environmental Science: Nano, 4, p.1484-1493, 2017.
  • Yi Jiang, Qingqing Zeng, Pratim Biswas, John Fortner, “Graphene Oxides as Nanofillers in Polysulfone Ultrafiltration Membranes: Shape Matters,” Journal of Membrane Science, 581, p.453-461, 2019.
  • Siyuan An, Jiewei Wu, Yao Nie, Wenlu Li, John D. Fortner, “Free chlorine induced phototransformation of graphene oxide in water: Reaction kinetics and product characterization,” Chemical Engineering Journal, 381, p.122609, 2020.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This NSF CAREER award focused on the development and demonstration of three dimensional (3D), nanoscale, crumpled graphene oxide (CGO) composites as multifunctional, platform materials for advanced water treatment. The project was designed with four interrelated foci that included novel material design and synthesis, material characterization, advanced applications in water treatment, and STEM education. The intellectual merit of this project was significant resulting in multiple, high-impact peer reviewed journal articles, a patent, and a number of presentations. Findings from the project were novel in that engineered, nanocomposite CGO materials had not been previously evaluated as platform materials for advanced, aqueous based photocatalysis or as multifunctional membrane components. Through this CAREER award, we demonstrate significant (nano)material/engineering advantages, including: intrinsic material porosities, highly tailorable photocatalytic and magnetic properties, tunable (carbon) surface chemistry and physical size/shape regimes, high aqueous and chemical stabilities, and scalable production routes. Taken together, data from the project underpin new and exciting directions for graphene based membranes (or even surfaces) with outstanding application potential. The fundamental nature of this work will also serve a wide range of researchers focused on engineering (curved) carbon-based nanostructures for advanced sensing, catalysts, photovoltaics, antifouling/antimicrobial surfaces, among other applied materials. With regard to broader impacts, this CAREER award directly benefits society as it provides fundamental scientific understanding and information to address the critical, global need for next-generation water treatment technologies. The award supported hands-on, project related, research opportunities for numerous undergraduate researchers and directly support four Ph.D. students, one winning a highly prestigious thesis award. Students gained highly interdisciplinary and collaborative experience(s) at the interface of material science, analytical chemistry, chemical engineering, and environmental engineering and science, allowing them to consider a diverse range of future STEM career paths.
